children.subject: Yes
If someone is pre-approved for CS, can they declare on day 1? Thus gaining the same priority enrollment in CS courses as EECS admits?
Asking because it seems like [whether you put CS-intended on your college application] is closely aligned to [what percentage of your high school class had parents that worked in the tech industry]

People who do not select CS as their intended major are held to a slightly higher bar in order to prevent people from "gaming" the system, or rather to have to worry about how to game the system, ie even though I am interested in CS, should I apply through another major to have a better shot? Now the answer is decidedly no, since you are held to a higher standard if you don't apply as CS. If you know you want to do CS, you should apply with CS as your intended major.

<md>Is there a higher standard if you don't apply as CS? The proposal slides say "All other L&S admits are also evaluated when they apply to Cal under the *same criteria of excellence and preparation.* Some of these admits will be pre-approved as well."</md>

If the intention is for a truthful mechanism, why not just don't consider what someone's intended major is? If you use the same standard for everyone, then there is no incentive to misrepresent your preference in either case, and there also isn't a disadvantage for people who come from communities where CS isn't a common career choice

That's harder to predict. It's likely that everyone who puts CS as their intended major and accepts their offer to enroll at Berkeley will declare CS as their major. On the other hand, the discoverer pool is much harder to know how many people out of that pool will end up majoring in CS. Part of the point is to make CS admissions numbers predictable and small after all.

It's not obvious that you should consider intended major, but there are a number of different effects that all together suggest CS-Intended students should have a lower bar. These reasons include (but are not limited to): Easier to predict yield (it's very hard to say how many non-intendeds will take the offer), intent to major in CS probably correlates with being able to succeed in courses, it's more disappointing to be denied from CS if you don't even care about it (so we make denial less likely for such students), and it's less drastic of a change from where we are today.

Is there a separate standard for pre-approval for CS-intended L&S vs. non-CS-intended L&S vs. students admitted to other colleges (like the College of Chemistry)? If so, what is the reasoning behind this?
Yes, that's the current plan, but could change. The exact language and mechanisms will take some time to figure out, and might require coordination with other impacted majors like Econ.
Are the people pre-approved who are non-CS-intended get notified at admission that they got pre-approved for CS?
I'd imagine that if you could not meet the bar for direct admissions you would also not meet the bar for pre-approval.

Man that would be wild; are people not worried about how incredibly elitist this proposal is? It basically reads as deciding that this CS approval status is above 1. people who get into Berkeley but aren’t “excellent” enough to be in CS, and 2. people who are waitlisted from Berkeley and work their asses off to get off said waitlist. Imposter syndrome is already enough of a problem within this school — imagine creating yet another way for students to feel unworthy before they’re even allowed to enter. :/

That's up to the office of admissions. I'm not certain how they decide who to waitlist but I'd assume it's people with relatively lower read scores. My guess is that your chances would not be good.

I think literally any system that allocates a scarce number of CS slots based on any sort of perceived merit will unfortunately feel elitist. We have this with the 3.3 GPA now, and I think it'd be even worse if the GPA cap were higher. 

A lottery (which we also discussed) would solve the elitism problem, but that comes with its own issues.

I see what you mean. My thoughts are just that at least people who try to declare with the GPA cap know what they’re getting themselves into. On the other hand, assigning people value based on whether they could “be successful” in one major right when they get into the school feels like a step above that in terms of elite-ness.

I dislike the GPA cap just as much as the next person & I respect/appreciate that y’all are putting so much work into finding a better way. I just imagine myself as a queer woman of color getting a “congrats you got into Berkeley as intended physics!! sorry you’re not worthy enough to ever study CS here though” and wondering why a major I wasn’t even applying to had the power to judge me in that way. It’s kind of like applying to Berkeley undergrad and getting a preemptive rejection from the grad school because they could never see you getting in. 

I know I’m not necessarily suggesting any better ideas & I don’t even think this is the most important piece of all this, but I do think it’s important to consider the implications & impact of giving unsolicited information.

I've personally chosen CAL because of its strong CS and Engineering programs and the world-renowned prestige and selectivity that comes with the name "Berkeley". Where I come from, graduating from a t20 college is essential to getting a prestigious job and garner respect from family members and friends. Most other CS programs in t20 schools are very selective. CMU selects only around 200 students and CMU is not even traditionally considered to be in the t20 schools. 

Although I respect and agree with your opinion that doors should be opened to minorities, while UC Berkeley was in a financial crisis, the faculty has lived up to Berkeley's obligation as a public school and admitted far more students into the cs department than it could handle. As this is becoming impractical as the number of students interested in CS is growing exponentially, I think Professor Hug, Professor Denero, and other EECS faculty had been very thoughtful in coming up with creative ways to open doors for students who haven't been coding since high school. As they mentioned, CS backgrounds in your UC application won't give you an advantage (which is very rare for private schools) and there are still multiple gateways for students to declare CS as discoverers (although they are selective). At USC/Ivy leagues, they will judge where your parents went to school, your parent's occupation, your scores and extracurriculars, and judge how likely you will be an elitist member of society in 20 years. UC Berkeley does no such thing. 

If students feel that "elitism" isn't for them, they could have easily chosen other institutions that aren't associated with prestige and selectivity. The CS industry only cares about what you can do, not where you went to school in the United States. It is perfectively reasonable for students to select other institutions and get into top-notch companies and have successful futures. Practically speaking, if you put 100 students who scored 1500+ on the SAT with 4.5+ GPA in a room, of course, they will be super proud of their accomplishments as they earned the title of "UC Berkeley student" and be "elitist" in your words about it.
Did you mean to respond to my post? I’m not calling students elitist nor did I mention minorities/the criteria used to pre-approve people.

Well, you said "are people not worried about how incredibly elitist this proposal is?", and gave a small anecdote about your experience as a minority applying to cs. Maybe my comment about students being elitist may be a little off, my general point was that Berkeley can't not be elitist (not be selective) and be the top public school at the same time. Although I think it is very unfortunate that fewer students will be able to study CS at CAL, considering the circumstances of CAL and its place in the rankings, I think this is one of the best CS decleartion proposals that attempts to answer all of your concerns. I would not want to see the GPA rise to 3.6+ that would bar most students who just started out CS in CAL from the major, considering how hard the 61 and 70 series are.

Ahhh I see what you’re saying. Yeah, when I mentioned my own identities I was more trying to point towards the fact that it’s already hard coming into a top school/STEM program with those backgrounds, much less hearing that you’re already being judged by your assumed abilities. Either way I totally understand that these schools will always have some form of elitism — I’d just rather see us work to combat them than be complacent with the fact that they’ll always exist, if that makes sense. We all have the same goal here, so even though this may be the best proposal to address these issues, I’d still like to see every issue considered.

Yeah, and I was just trying to offer a different perspective than the American one ("it doesn't matter where you go to school"), and being "elitist" is bad. In Asia, and perhaps other more collective societies, selectivity and prestige are very important when choosing schools. It isn't always pleasant when your uncle compares you with his son who went to med school or gets labeled as "stupid" by friends. It's sort of like a "family honor" thing. Perhaps this policy will convince an international student to choose Berkeley CS over Northwestern CS for example? Just a different way of thinking about it.

BTW Alison this exact concern is one reason why we might not proactively notify the students who are not pre-approved. One way this could work is that there is a website people can use to check their status. Ideally only people who actually care about CS will bother to check.
Will folks who are waitlisted at Berkeley & then taken off the waitlist have a chance at being pre-approved? If so, what are the number estimates there? Apologies if this was answered already.

People do actually pursue L&S CS and CoE differently, e.g. people with double majors, so I think it makes sense that both degrees exist, but yes the differences are not very big for most people.

Speaking only for myself, I think a single admissions process is the right way to go, but that is a far harder goal to accomplish since it requires coordination with so many other campus entities.

We'll be communicating as clearly as possible to the outside world. This new system is at least better, since the admissions rate will be nearly the same for L&S CS and EECS. 

Regarding last slide: With the current data, it's hard to say. There seem to be a lot of people who pick an L&S major other than L&S CS but actually intended to do CS because they think that picking CS will disadvantage them at admissions. The committee had a spirited debate about how many "discoverers" vs. "intendeds" there are currently. We have some estimates but I'm not sure anybody feels confident in their answer. I'll think about this some more and get back to you next week.

Thank you so much for the follow-up, Professor. If the admission rates are going to be similar and both give you guarantee of getting the major when you apply now that helps relieve some of the struggle to decide which one to apply to. This proposal would make that process more straightforward and help applicants in that way.

Again, thank you so much for your thoughtful response and your time.

I was wondering why there couldn't be a single CS major. When I was applying, I had a lot of difficulty determining whether to apply L&S CS or EECS. I ended up applying L&S CS intended to lower risk of not getting in at all and because I would have the control over being able to declare. With this proposal there would still be this guessing game about whether to apply L&S or EECS to increase your chances. In reality, there isn't much difference in the coursework, and I don't really believe most L&S or EECS majors are too concerned about most of the differences. Clearing this up with one determination at admission might be very useful to applicants.

Also, for the last slide is there data about the percent of CS-intended that end up declaring vs non-CS intended at time of applying that declare?

I believe from the presentation part of the reasoning was to keep the LS spirit of discovery. Some people may not enter Berkeley knowing they'd want to study CS. Some subset of those people will be earmarked to be eligible to major in CS afterwards.

The reason it's not all petition based is that the late admit can cause issues for students. If you're a sophomore and you are rejected for the petition, now what? You've spent two years at an institution where you can't major in what you want. 

Instead, if your preapproval status is given to you at admissions, you can just choose to go another school if you are not preapproved but were admitted.

I can't speak for the whole committee, but my personal fear was that if all CS-intendeds had to go through a holistic application process (which accepted 100 students per year instead of 10-20 people accepted through special petition), we'd end up having an even higher pressure gauntlet than we do now to enter the major that literally every single discoverer would have to face. Being a discoverer is already hard. This would make it harder. 

To make matters worse, we'd also probably have CS-intended students pretending to be not interested in CS so that they could try to go through the petition route, so holistic applications would also have to include a step where we tried to figure out if you were actually intended but just pretending to be a discoverer.

Generally: I personally want maximum clarity as early as possible so students' futures don't get derailed suddenly because they fail to jump through some hoop possibly years into their time into college.

That makes sense Professor Hug, but what criteria will we use to earmark people who did not apply CS intended to CS? Is it fair to assume that the people admissions selects are going to be the people who would have otherwise "discovered" CS?

To me, it makes more sense to allocate those seats to people who actually want to do CS (ie CS intended folks). As an added support, that's how most other colleges do it: you apply to CS and get in, not apply to something else and get into CS.

Also Professor Hug, I'm not sure why having 100 students accepted would be less pressure than 10-20 students accepted by petition in your statement above. Wouldn't more students accepted by petition = higher acceptance rate = less pressure?

What's the point in pre-approving people who are not CS intended for CS - they haven't indicated that they even want to do CS? Why don't we just let them "discover" and let more than 10 people in for that bucket?
It'd probably be like the current situation for EECS - possible, but unlikely.

Such students would have to either go through the L&S petition process or transfer into CoE and be an EECS transfer. The path would definitely be considerably narrower than it is today. It isn't feasible to pre-approve non L&S students because of the way admissions works on campus.

Many students admitted to other colleges such as CoC or CNR decide later that they would like to study CS instead. With this policy, does the possibility of switching to L&S and declaring CS almost vanish for them?
Yep, at the very earliest, this will only affect students entering Fall 2022 or later.
Hello, I just wanted to confirm (either from a faculty member or advisor) that the 3.3 GPA cap will be honored for current students at Berkeley/students admitted before Fall 2022. Thank you.

The exact details and degree to which classes will shrink is undecided, but a bedrock idea behind the proposal is that we will continue to offer classes at a size sufficient to allow EECS/CS majors entering Spring 2022 or earlier to have the same course accessibility as students currently do. Basically as the larger pool of current students graduate, we'll tune the course sizes down. It'll be Fall 2026 before we end up at the new steady state, though even then it's possible that we'll be fundraising to be able to expand beyond course sizes again.

Another bedrock principle is that we will continue to support an open data science major. It's feasible that e.g. 189 ends up being hard to get into for DS majors before then, but if that happens, there will be a replacement scalable course specifically built to support non-CS majors.
The slides said you guys are planning to decrease capacity of upper division CS courses. When will this happen? Will this happen before I (declared CS major) graduate or after?

I think 300 was chosen so the CS major enrollments would align with EECS enrollments. But, I think you bring up a good point -- why is 300 the right number? Maximizing opportunities for the most students is important but it trades off with the quality of education Berkeley can guarantee for each individual student. 

MIT seems to have more than >500 CS majors. CMU's CS enrollment numbers seem much more in line with the vision of the proposal, though I couldn't find anything on how many students transfer to CS within CMU. Berkeley's current numbers decimate any comparable program though.

And it's noticeable. In 270, we peer grade each other's HW. 70 has to subsample HW questions to grade introducing considerable randomness into student grade outcomes. The expected wait times on OH queue can be patently absurd. Another point that was a brought up is there's a severe shortage in research and other opportunities for students interested in grad school. 

Just off a feeling, I think 300 is way too severe a reduction. Ideally, I'd love to know what are the challenges the EECS department finds most pressing with the current overenrollment and why 300 is the right size for the future CS community.

<md>@Helix:

500 is just a working number. It might be less, we'll see. We're constrained in two ways: budget and faculty bandwidth. 

Budget wise: the department is running huge deficits and the temporary measures that have kept us temporarily above water cannot persist. This is true even with many classes now operating much leaner than before (lower $$/student). 

Faculty bandwidth wise: Huge classes have led to more co-teaching, which leads to fewer course offerings. Our grad classes have taken the biggest hit. And it's not just in classes, but in opportunities to pursue research, get mentorship, letters of recommendation etc. Some faculty are also getting pretty burned out. While the workload doesn't scale linearly with number of students it does grow with student population. It is very hard to effectively run a thousand person class, run a research group, and do all the various service things that faculty to do. 

If this proposal is passed we'll do a more careful analysis of just how much we need to cut to get to a sustainable place. And even if we do cut by 500, hopefully we can fundraise to hire more TAs and faculty to continue growth later. 

Your concern is indeed a massive concern. 500 people is a lot of people who don't get to do CS at Berkeley. There are a few mitigating factors that make me feel better: One is that data science is staying open. Since data science is an interdisciplinary field where a student has a focus outside of the core discipline itself, that gives us more breathing room. That is CS students might take something like 15 EECS courses total, but data science is more like maybe 7 or 8. Given that lots of students are able to get on track for a professional career shortly after 61B, it may be that all the upper divs like W186/164/162 etc. are not truly necessary to get your foot in the door to the technology industry, if indeed that is your goal. I also think that data science is more likely to build students into people who are going to contribute to society rather than create widgets for extractive businesses. After all, data science is about producing insight. A bit of a digression, but it makes me feel a little better.

Another mitigating factor is that CS at Berkeley produces only a small fraction of CS degrees in the state/world. There are also all of the other UCs and Cal State schools. I have a suspicion that many of our less prepared students would have had a much better experience at say Davis. I went to a way less intense undergrad (UT Austin) and would not have had nearly as good a time if I had been a Berkeley undergrad. Again this is only a vague suspicion and is a mitigating factor that makes me feel better. 

tl;dr Hopefully we won't have to cut as much as 500. Even if we do, hopefully we can continue to grow in the future back up to meet demand.</md>

<md>@Abinav: 

Rough number of CS students graduating per year (B.S. or B.A.) vs. number of CS faculty:

MIT: 680 : 94
Stanford: 330 : 63
CMU: 173 : 70
UW: 450 : 72
Berkeley; 1100 : 61

Berkeley numbers above include CS oriented EECS students and L&S CS. You can see ratio is far far beyond all peer institutions.</md>

Hey I just submitted the form above with much more personal detail, but paraphrasing here to start some discussion:

Do we really need to scale down by 500 people??

In my opinion, Reducing over HALF the amount of CS majors for slightly more individualized help and less stress it totally not worth it. Imagine all of the future lives of students you are fundamentally changing by denying them the access and opportunity to do CS (sure they can go to other schools and give it a go there, but that is OUR loss). IMO, this is absolutely more important than the small benefits we would receive by slashing the program size. I would support a 10% reduction, so enrollment is more guaranteed. Any further reduction is not worth it. Classes are fine as how they are right now. They certainly could be improved, but most classes are not dumpster fires. Sure, they could definitely be improved with smaller classes and more individualized help. And sure, stress can be moved to high school instead of college. But that is simply not worth denying an equitable opportunity for 500 more people to discover or pursue CS.

I do agree the solution is not perfect, but I wanted to address the "discover CS portion" of your argument. My question mainly is, how and why do these people discover CS? Playing devil's advocate here, but is it because they saw the huge salaries right out of undergrad and that persuaded them to do CS? Not saying that is everyone, but I feel more often than not that is the case. Sure, there are some people who discover CS very late into their time at Berkeley and try to switch, but there are also some people who discover CS in their first semester freshman year, and end up never taking a single class in the major they applied for. I personally think the new proposed system where students who don't explicitly say they are interested in studying CS have a small percentage getting pre-approved for is a good change, simply because at least where I am from (South Bay), many people applying each year all play the same tricks to get in i.e. applying for a less "competitive" major in L&S and then immediately switching to CS.

I think there's always going to be people who go into CS for money, and to be honest, I don't think that's a bad thing. If your family is in a lower socioeconomic situation, who are we to say that CS pursued for passion is better than money. It's always easier to care about passion when you don't have any economic concerns. But it's basically impossible to divine whether someone does it for money or passion, so I think that it's not worth pursuing either way.

<md>If you're just concerned about the number honestly that doesn't really have anything to do with the proposal. In fact, it's better, since the number of students admitted is easily controlled. As Hug stated above:

>500 is just a working number. It might be less, we'll see. We're constrained in two ways: budget and faculty bandwidth.

>Budget wise: the department is running huge deficits and the temporary measures that have kept us temporarily above water cannot persist. This is true even with many classes now operating much leaner than before (lower $$/student).

>Faculty bandwidth wise: Huge classes have led to more co-teaching, which leads to fewer course offerings. Our grad classes have taken the biggest hit. And it's not just in classes, but in opportunities to pursue research, get mentorship, letters of recommendation etc. Some faculty are also getting pretty burned out. While the workload doesn't scale linearly with number of students it does grow with student population. It is very hard to effectively run a thousand person class, run a research group, and do all the various service things that faculty to do.

>If this proposal is passed we'll do a more careful analysis of just how much we need to cut to get to a sustainable place. And even if we do cut by 500, hopefully we can fundraise to hire more TAs and faculty to continue growth later.</md>

I feel like you can't just throw money at this problem and try to solve it. One big factor that is hurting minorities I think is the exam-based assessment system many CS classes have chosen to take due to huge class sizes. It hurts students who aren't great exam takers and can't gain more ground in projects since exams are the only thing that matters in their grade and doesn't reward creativity and different learning paces students may have. In CS50 at Harvard, with the low faculty to staff ratio, students can choose to pursue their own projects at the end of the semester, which accounts for a lot of their grade. 

Also, it seems like you have had great access to what the CS major had to offer by getting into clubs like CSM and becoming a UGSI, which is great, but many students are simply not given the opportunity to improve and gain new research and teaching experiences due to the competitive <5% acceptance rates from CS-related research opportunities, clubs, and teaching opportunities. Many students aren't able to be seen as qualified by companies after graduation, not because they were lazy, but since everyone rejected them their freshman/sophomore year and are left with nothing to do but attend classes. This was a big problem for my peers and many others (I'm assuming) who are intended/declared CS and EECS. You just can't funnel money into the program, hire more TAs and fix these problems. We have to reduce the student-faculty ratio. The biggest reason why UCLA is ranked higher than Berkeley in undergrad is that UCLA cared about what environments students were studying in and worked to improve the student/faculty ratio and consequently, have a lower admissions rate. 

I care a lot about students being exposed to CS, but I care more about students being exposed to lots of research/teaching/extracurricular opportunities (not the <5% acceptance rate Berkeley ones), are in a comfortable breathable environment, and that students are accessed in all areas when assigning grades, not just exams. The current proposal will fix a lot of these problems, and I think it is a better way forward.

This proposal is very concerning to me for several reasons. First, is the process. Although not directly related, it's very reminiscent of the housing crisis and the approval process for developments. The thousands of people who will be greatly affected in both cases are not here to represent their views - instead we have students who won't be affected at all. Obviously, people would be much more apathetic to these changes.

Second, where is the communication or effort in finding an alternative solution that doesn't drastically affect thousands of students in the future. Is this the only option or simply the easiest to implement? If the problem is funding, instead of cutting costs by 66 percent, could we find new sources of funding and have all those avenues been attempted? There are probably tens or hundreds of thousands of alumni in the tech industry, and perhaps if an urgent campaign was even attempted, this problem could be greatly reduced through a fund. I find it hard to believe that a public campaign with student backing couldn't raise a lot more money through alumni or tech companies in one of the wealthiest industry and community. Couldn't the expansion in 61c last semester from Apple be emulated in some way? And it seems like there are only a few classes that are extremely popular and need to find additional funding.  The point is that there seem to be a lot of different ways to raise revenue, either through more lobbying of the administration or finding new sources of revenue in creative ways. We could innovate with different models and be on the forefront of new educational systems. It could be that all of those public efforts fail, but it certainly would not hurt, and could reduce the impact to 1/2, 1/3 or a 1/4 cut instead. This proposal just seems like the easiest path, but affects the greatest number of people negatively. And if we're having problems with fundraising now, why would cutting access to students help in any form.

Third, as the leading public university, we should raise the bar in equitable access. This proposal seems to hurt one group tremendously. The people who would not have majored in CS if not for the excellent CS community, teachers, and TA's. I count myself as being part of that group. Yes, there are problems with large class sizes, and we can do much better in mitigating those problems. But the fact remains that these large class sizes and the large CS community at Berkeley has contributed to a culture of excellence and pride. Only at Berkeley can someone with no experience switch into CS, join clubs like CSM, and become a valued and excellent TA during the semester or even one of the summer instructors. With this proposal, we would be losing a massive group of people who contribute to the success of Berkeley. I saw a reply above saying that students who struggled to declare might have a better time at another UC, like UC Davis. I had a difficult time getting past the cap where I had to late drop a class, but I would certainly say that I belong here and would not wish to go anywhere else for an easier path. Furthermore, the career outcomes and graduation rate for CS and EECS now are essentially equivalent. 

Finally, does this proposal even solve the problem? Essentially, we are telling future students that whenever they discover CS is right for them, they should have a DS degree instead. It's already obvious what will happen in a few years. DS will be extremely full, and those students will want to take CS classes as well. The demand for CS classes is not going to go down even if the degree is not in CS. So the most likely outcome is those students who would have graduated with a CS degree instead graduate with a DS degree with a much harder time in enrolling in classes. If the base problem of demand for CS classes won't decrease, what is the point of this proposal then? It just pushes the problem into a different department and keeps pressure on CS classes.

A few years ago, I heard a proposal from a professor that made a lot of sense to me and I'm wondering why it was not taken. It was to essentially have a CS honors track where they could take specialized small classes and a regular CS track where the classes were large and could expand with TA's and graduate instructors teaching. This proposal actually addresses the core problem - demand - and doesn't just cut the department by 2/3's. Obviously there are different problems, but they are much better problems to have. 

TLDR: This proposal doesn't address the root problem of demand, causes equitable access problems, and is extremely drastic. The people who would be most affected have no say. Have we tried to address the problem of funding in other ways that actually increase funding rather than lower costs? And there are better proposals that would actually address the problem.

As someone who chose to focus in EE rather than CS in large part because of the awful culture and environment created by the GPA cap, I find this conversation fairly interesting. The undergrad EE program has, in a sense, the opposite problem to that of the undergrad CS program(s): all students that graduate having focused in EE are "discoverers", since most are admitted against the higher standard of the EECS (really CS) filter and all EECS lower division coursework is designed with CS as the primary focus. This leaves people in the EECS (really CS) community here with the distorted sense that EE is somehow a dying field or something like that, when, in fact, it is a very popular major at most other universities (e.g. EE was the second most popular undergrad engineering major at UCLA in 2018) and opens pathways to many stable, high-paying jobs after graduation. This might be unimaginable to people in this community, but, in my internships, I've often encountered people that were blown away that I got the chance to study EE at Berkeley and completely dumbfounded when they learned that very few undergraduate students actually take this path here. 

This might be a crazy idea (and I know people in the department think so, since it was shot down when I suggested it in this Piazza four years ago), but maybe making an "EE-intended" path is something the department should try as well. You could call it the "electrical engineering" major and let EECS exist for people that want to "discover" their path (with CS as the in-built default option). 

Like I said, it's probably crazy of me to want to expand access to Berkeley's fantastic EE upper-div classes to applicants that are passionate about EE but don't necessarily meet the cutoff for EECS (really CS), but I felt like I should put it out there (again).

history.content:
Dear Students, please see the below message from Professor Josh Hug who hosted yesterday's Town Hall on CS Reform.

Best wishes,
Susanne
---
Hi all, thanks to everyone who participated in the Town Hall on February 12th.
If you missed it, you can access the Town Hall materials here:

Proposal Video (first 13 minutes, Q&A follows): https://drive.google.com/file/d/1HZuDm1ZM74LCgIDhzZwrfBWa_GeSh5_r
Slides: https://docs.google.com/presentation/d/1f1mcwIopXcSg_fNhFp7_CnP1eG_T9S_AmXEVR6gA2RM
Zoom chat (pseudonymized): https://drive.google.com/file/d/1Kz8GU7GVBqwfasJSZGeTVySEhUj6zxDA
Please provide your feedback, especially including any concerns or suggested changes at this link: https://forms.gle/erCN4TLNKDY8dCW87
Thanks!
Josh Hug
(on behalf of the L&S major declaration committee)
history.subject: Town Hall Video and Slides from 2/12, Request for Feedback
